instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no power.
It takes 5.16V from ampmeter and 0A.
I have 5.16V on F4700 and 0V on <SIGNAL>3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL>.

Diode Readings:

<SIGNAL>3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> = 0.331
<SIGNAL>E85_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.555
<SIGNAL>E85_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.555

I supose that it can be related with <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>. Am I right?
Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4700</CHIP>/80 are the first suspects on this board.
Can be also faulty <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I alreay replaced <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>/80 and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, but with the same result.
What more can i check?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Check basic voltage for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, ACIN, VDDA/P.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Didn't find corresponding line to <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>?
What about <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Sorry, I've missed that.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> = 5.177V
<RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> seams to be OK. I get 5.177V on the 4 pads

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
At least one of <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR>/04 is burnt.
And possibly one of <CAPACITOR>C7100</CAPACITOR>/01 bad too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

<RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR> = 0 ohm
<RESISTOR>R7104</RESISTOR> = 4.6 ohm

<CAPACITOR>C7100</CAPACITOR>/01 seams to be ok, but I've  removed both. However, I still have the same behavier.
<SIGNAL>CHGR_LDO_P5V0</SIGNAL> (on <RESISTOR>R7104</RESISTOR>) = -0.141V
Shall I replace  <RESISTOR>R7101</RESISTOR>/04 ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I've got confused between voltage and diode mode at VDDA/P pins, sorry.
However, you should change <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> again.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I don't have any more of those. Can I take from a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board? Do you know any good suplier for them?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: It should work from 00244 donor board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I've replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> again (twice), but same thing. However I get some strange readings (I think):
I've used 2 multimeters and in <SIGNAL>CHGR_LDO_VDDA</SIGNAL> I get negative voltages (-0.221V), and on <SIGNAL>CHGR_LDO_P5V0</SIGNAL> I get -0.080V. Does this make any sense to you?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Do you think that I should give up on it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
If <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is good for sure and properly soldered, then must have a problem with surrounding components.
Check diode mode to ground at L7095 and F7140.
